Though the following might read like faint praise, "The Hangover Part III" closes out what's likely the best comedy trilogy of all time, and on a genuinely respectable note.
[Peter Jackson's] efforts to filter or self-edit - assuming there were any - remain fruitless.
A modest but definite improvement on its predecessor.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Jackson has finally given his beloved series an appropriately fiery Viking's funeral, setting it aflame and pushing its decaying corpse out to nowhere in particular.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It glosses over what exactly made Alan Turing so brilliant, resulting in a monochromatic picture that could have been - should have been - told in bright, striking color.
[Laps] itself in a race towards tastelessness that no one asked it to run.
The film is completely unique and its sci-fi bent is fully realized in a way that some sci-fi films fail to capture.
Director Seth Gordon's best film since his brilliant debut, "The King Of Kong: A Fistful Of Quarters."
Writer-director Stuart Beattie and his cast and crew tear into their bad idea with vigor.
The casting of Bill Murray as Franklin Delano Roosevelt is just one of many quirks that makes [the film] the enjoyable diversion that it is.
A series that just a few years ago seemed to bubble with personality and intrigue and depth is closed out here as coldly as possible.
Half a story stretched far too thin with a cast that has neither reason nor opportunity to stretch themselves.
Whereas "The Hunger Games" made for some interesting political commentary, "Catching Fire" is content to rest on its laurels, adding nothing to the conversation.
With a joke well that runs dry nearly an hour too early, watches will be checked and previously unwanted popcorn kernels will be rigorously examined.
Classic Saturday morning cartoon material, very silly and very much aimed at 5 year-olds.
It's rare to see a group of gifted comedians be so damn boring, to watch so much legitimate goodwill be blown to smithereens.
Kind of like watching a toddler assemble a high-end bookcase.
Rampant racism, misogyny, and homophobia serve as placeholders where actual jokes might have been, with Jennifer Aniston suffering the worst of it.
There are parts of the film that work beautifully, all of which feature Jones' innate ability to emote with a look, a gesture, or a sigh.
"In The Heart Of The Sea" is so flat it could be used to level a table.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film of mythic incompetence, the most uproariously ill-conceived studio picture since Nicolas Cage's "Wicker Man" remake.
At times it displays an almost alarming level of contempt for its audience.
The breadth of the subject matter tirelessly works against director Lee Daniels and company, leading to some inevitably goofy casting choices and unfortunate make-up work.
That the pacing is glacial hardly matters - at least for the first hour or so - because Larry Smith's cinematography is so breathtaking.
[The movie] takes delight in its own unoriginality, dancing on the grave of every loud, dumb, preposterous action film of the past twenty years. Without earning any of it.
It's captivating to watch Spike Lee dabble in genre filmmaking.
"Oculus" plays like it went straight to DVD in 2005, its over-reliance on technology as a plot device and distractingly bad hair making it feel instantly dated.
A frequently uneasy potluck of mixed emotional terrain, hit-and-miss jokes, and one transcendent performance that impressively, if messily, ties it all together.
Is it better to bore an audience or to annoy them? "Oblivion" answers that question enthusiastically - "Why choose one when you can have both!?"
[Bullock] singlehandedly muscles the film from second-generation David O. Russell Xerox to something worth seeing.
Like a car that all at once blows its transmission, loses power steering, succumbs to a flat tire, and catches fire, "Now You See Me" is a wreck in every sense of the word.
"Non-Stop" sees Liam Neeson resume his generic action hero persona - as seen in "Taken" and "Unknown" - to far less successful results.
As misguided a film as you're likely to see from a genuinely great filmmaker.
It's too pointless to be even a guilty pleasure, plunging past "low rent" into "no rent" territory, dragging two competent performers down into the mud with it.
"No Escape" plays like an "Argo" rewrite by someone who heard about "Argo" from a friend who never saw "Argo."
Sinister and upsetting and strangely magnetic - as the best movie monsters are - Gyllenhaal rises above the intermittently pedestrian screenplay.
Nicholas Stoller's "Neighbors" is nothing short of furious in its jabs, hooks, and uppercuts at the funny bone.
[The film] very deliberately trades on whatever nostalgia moviegoers might have left for Pierce Brosnan as a secret agent, and ticket-buyers' mileage will vary accordingly.
The narrative is so straightforward that it requires the kind of flashbang storytelling that Cooper clearly isn't interested in.
For as high it soars in its opening twenty-five minutes, its midsection falls just as flat, before its director takes back the reigns in time for an exceptional finale.
"Pacific Rim" puts the "disaster" in "disaster movie."
There's some terrific stuff going on here, its minimalist bent and gorgeous photography combining to form a quietly immense dramedy that should age very well.
It's weightless and graceless, complete with a stock love story, a cloying human interest angle, and no shortage of poor acting.
The techno-centric storyline does little to separate it from the last decade of subpar horror.
It's rare to see a picture so bogged down by the breadth of its ambition, but Derek Cianfrance's second feature nearly collapses under its own weight.
Bad movie "Pixels" is just the latest pock mark on Adam Sandler's still downtrending career, only noteworthy in its unprecedented slothfulness.
The multitude of references to ["The Breakfast Club"] backfires in a major way, but it's a worthwhile lesson to burgeoning filmmakers - don't invoke John Hughes. Don't.
What it gets right is so right that the occasional clunky piece of dialogue or the slip of an accent isn't enough to derail a lovely piece of cinema.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Clement's predilection for center stage is real and actually kind of astounding, pole-vaulting James Strouse's low-key romantic comedy into something much sturdier.
The movie is an appeal to the most general audience possible, lacking the necessary spark to find the right audience.
As warm and inviting as a baby blue blanket, handily walking a line between old and new.
Its desire to tell a small part of a historical firebrand's story is undermined by its reluctance - or inability - to get inside his mind.
Director Robert Luketic [does] nothing beyond his contractual obligations (which presumably read, "Um, make a movie, I guess").
By placing weighty, real world lessons aimed at kids in this specific cinematic world, the gloominess is only intensified.
Destined to play second banana to last year's critical and commercial darling "The Fault In Our Stars." But as second bananas go, it's not a bad one.
Bay's worst film to date and the biggest piece of evidence yet in the case against him.
The amount of fun a cast and crew have while making a movie rarely translates to the final product, but that's not the case here.
Dern's line delivery alone - all of his lines are delivered as if he was just awakened from a deep sleep, a flashlight thrust in his face - is worth the price of admission,
Knowingly pokes fun at its duties as a sequel - and the disappointment that usually comes with follow-ups - and the results are more than satisfactory.
[Treats] its audience to a steady stream of enjoyable human-versus-monster setpieces and delightful dummy-based physical comedy.
For viewers willing to put up with a largely pointless story, there are still revelations to be had in "Magic Mike XXL." They're just harder to come by this time around.
[A] perfect storm of marketability and smart, inventive avant-garde cinema - a resourceful character piece built upon a cacophony of cinematic contrast.
Woody Allen devotees might appreciate the piece as a fleeting glimpse into the bizarre personal life of its creator, but mainstream audiences should pay no mind.
A wildly monotonous film that operates at one volume - fortissimo - bludgeoning us over the head into either submission or exhaustion.
The stunt casting is so poorly realized that actors pop in and out of the film at random, the story apparently stitched together according to actors' schedules.
It's an antagonistically unintelligent piece, one that clearly views itself as equal parts entertaining and profound. It's neither.
While the film overshoots its landing by a mile, it's a worthwhile science fiction piece with no shortage of interesting ideas.
"Lone Survivor" isn't a classic, but it's a modestly affecting war pic that artfully pays tribute to some real American heroes - exactly what it sets out to do.
If 1999's "Wild Wild West" was the deathblow for the big budget western, "The Lone Ranger" is the belated shower of dirt that should finally put the genre to rest.
Daniel Day-Lewis' performance is one-note, but what a note it is!
[Director] Ang Lee's strongest work to date.
[A] succinct and often hilarious retelling of a life well lived.
It's hard not to appreciate the pic's devil-may-care attitude, Johnson's prickly-but-likable screen persona, and Wayans' effortless channeling of his famous father.
Tom Hooper, what have you done?
It's hard to imagine a more inspired Lego film, or one less concerned with selling toys.
Its highs are modest, but it never shortchanges its audience on spectacle or thoughtfulness or loving but frustrated nostalgia for its source material.
A stylish, streamlined, and thrilling prohibition era action yarn.
A gigantic leap forward for the mannequin acting community.
The most colossally mediocre sci-fi movie of the decade, all in pursuit of empty backslapping and a grade school level celebration of science.
A bittersweet curtain call for the late Philip Seymour Hoffman.
The piece works best as an audio-video experience, uniquely tying together its period piece trappings with a wonderful soundtrack.
The movie is a worthy warning to Hollywood at large: if you're going to make a comedy, hire some damn comedians.
This is the work of an auteur - confident, but understated; beautiful, but heartbreaking; intoxicating, but sobering.
Plays like an outtake reel interspersed with scenes of real dramatic weight, making for one of the most uneven cinematic rides in recent memory.
Breezy and charming enough to warrant a viewing - especially for younger audiences.
An eminently quotable look at the vast differences between millennials born just ten years apart.
[A] mostly dialogue-free, opera-set sequence is a thing of blunt-force beauty, choreographed, executed, and shot as well as any fight scene ever.
When today's youth inevitably look back on their favorite tiny, yellow, goggled henchman, they won't be thinking of this movie.
Hamm and Bell have real chemistry together and the supporting players - apart from Arkin's perfunctory performance - uniformly keep pace with the leads.
Giddily preposterous.
If Reitman's aim was to push buttons, make us think, and give his cast a stage for some stellar performances, he's succeeded wildly.
Its Sundance buzz wears off well before the end credits roll.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: ["The Maze Runner"] never delivers on its early potential, quickly falling down a chute of one-note characters and painfully sparse storytelling.
Joaquin Phoenix's performance is dazzling, the kind of effort we're lucky to see once every two or three years.
[Henry Cavill's] only apparent superpower is boring the audience.
No matter how predictable the journey, the visuals and heart-tugging moments are both timeless and top of the line.
Maddeningly episodic.
Instead of expounding on the exposed nerve of the book, Fincher's adaptation settles for mere abrasion.
Viewers thirsty for a lecture on collateralized debt obligations from celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain are in for a treat.
"Big Hero 6" is a mish-mash of mixed messages, from its "compassion over violence, through violence" finale to its clumsily appropriated Japanese stylistic flourishes.
A lovingly crafted, uncommonly astute look at gender roles in American families.
The authenticity that was in inherent in "Once" is lost here on a cast of movie stars, and the music isn't quite good enough to elevate a cloying screenplay.
It never finds any kind of balance, going from tasteful but kind of dull to inane and sort of captivating.
The first two acts are so beautifully harrowing, so warm and generous in the face of abject horror that its third act turn to mediocrity feels like an impossible plunge.
Packs motion picture, stage play, graphic novel, and gossip column into one surprisingly accessible 100-minute package, tying it together with ribbons of scalding satire.
The film's dialogue is so crude, its star so inherently - and paradoxically - likable, and its plot so lightweight that it essentially cancels itself out.
Come for the dread, stay for the subtext, and top it all off with a little nightlight shopping on Amazon.
As a deliberate extension of multiple brands all at once, as the latest lily pad to Marvel's next big thing, it's a solid success, if not much in the way of an evolution.
This cast and crew is so well suited to bring this story to life that it's nearly serendipitous, and the film will play like catnip to fans of the play.
It's [Perdita Weeks'] strangely believable performance that saves the film from itself, planting us firmly in its corner, often against our will.
It's so sleek and well-made that you'll wish you could park it in your driveway and show it off to your neighbors.
"Ant-Man" is far too restrained to stand out amongst its peers, too careful to leave a lasting mark of its own. Its pleasures are real, but nearly as small as its hero.
For the creators of "Super Troopers" and "Beerfest," two comedies with devoted followings, "The Babymakers" is a pretty serious setback.
A mélange of undercooked characters with nothing to say and nowhere to go.
[Hemsworth] spends much of the film tapping away on keyboards, frequently looking down at his hands - no, really, the expert computer hacker looks at his hands to type.
Avoid "Blended" like it's your job - because it is. Your future happiness could depend on it.
Hanks is very good in the role - downright fantastic in its final minutes - his everyman persona going a long way in eliciting attachment on the part of the audience.
Its heroes are weird, broken people, its villains facades of prosperity and authority, and the stakes conversely high - the fate of the world - and deeply personal.
The leads do fine work, but the screenplay bizarrely reduces Ferrell to straight man for much of the film.
More traumatic than enjoyable, but there's great beauty in both its scenery and the way McDonagh and his cast cut through us with surgical precision.
A surprisingly proficient thriller - even more proficient for the viewer who bails before the final scene.
A weird, austere, picturesque, wannabe art film that ticks most of the boxes it's trying to tick and manages not to bore for most of its running time.
A worthy callback to Stallone's glory days.
The essence of "Broken City" is forgettable, and that's its only strength. Once it's over, you won't be bothered to think about it ever again.
It's rare to see a protagonist who's so gently human, so righteously patriotic, and so believable, making "Bridge Of Spies" one of the most striking spy movies ever made.
Fit to be condemned.
Everything here is tied together beautifully, at an inimitably comfortable pace.
There's no hand-holding here on the part of Linklater, who presents these events devoid of theatrics, as true to life as fiction can be.
It won't provide the cinematic jolt that many are looking for in a "Bourne" film.
"Blue Jasmine" is that rare film that's both a true ensemble piece and a showcase for its lead.
At best, the picture can be written off as some kind of failed experiment, a competition to see which cast member is the most in tune with his or her inner dolt.
Its etherealness is not unfamiliar territory for Kaufman, but his way of making the familiar seem unfamiliar carries the day, as always.
In the hands of a better creative team, an all-Annabelle film might have been a grand slam. Here it's a bloop single, narrowly avoiding a tag out on the basepaths.
It's absolutely stuffed with jokes, its pointed criticism of the news media is a natural fit, and the cast is uniformly energized.
Does what it sets out to do, expertly weaving together the monotony of everyday life, the nauseating horror of mortality, and the most esoteric corners of the human mind.
The end result should attract and repel moviegoers in the same degree, virtually refusing an easy ranking among the Coens' filmography. Would that it were so simple.
Not quite a debacle, not at all a success, it ends up a thoroughly inconsequential adaptation that's unlikely to shepherd a new wave of mash-ups to the big screen.
"Deadpool" is with spirit but without gumption, smarts, or conviction.
It's anything but a sure thing for mainstream horror audiences, a ride best taken with expectations in check and a healthy taste for metaphor.
It's hokum, but the best kind... accessible to just about everyone with a pulse.
The comedy merely exists alongside a very ordinary action movie outline, rarely crossing paths and never working in concert.
A film that willfully punts audience patience and goodwill into the stratosphere in its closing reel.
If there are a few sweet moments between Rauch and Middleditch here, they're all but erased by an ineffectual story... and an admittedly impressive void of genuine laughs.
Two fine lead performances interred in a film that's flatter than a silver dollar pancake.
If the film is superficially great, a plastered-over screenplay lurks just beneath, poking its ugly head out early and often.
A momentum-less ode to uncreative people everywhere that torches two of pop culture's greatest characters and uses their ashes as a urinal cake.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the great cinematic thrill rides, a masterful piece of genre-hopping pop spectacle.
A shock-rock bullet train of a thriller that's likely to grow in esteem even faster than "Blue Ruin" has. [Writer-director] Jeremy Saulnier has arrived.
Jean-Marc Vallée's supremely confident "Demolition" breezes through 100 minutes of grief and catharsis on the back of yet another dazzling performance from Jake Gyllenhaal.
It's anything but a breezy journey, but it's a deeply rewarding one for those unafraid of serious, heartbreaking, contemplative, nerve-hitting cinema.
Stiller's sequel lazily swaps out satire for celebrity cameos, memorable musical cues for different iterations of the same songs, and a childlike Derek for a cruel one.
The period trappings remain impeccable throughout, crackling even when the script doesn't.
Armed with a terrific cast and suspense and poignancy to spare, [director Gavin Hood's] long-awaited return to independent film is a keeper.
By the climax, in which the duo literally shoots their way through torrents of falling cash, we're left to wonder if the whole film was engineered for that moment.
"American Ultra" improbably has more gore and fewer laughs than "American Sniper," a distinction that makes it sound a lot more compelling that it is.
Cooper is very good in the film, bulking up to built fat status, mostly nailing Kyle's southern lilt, and selling the inner turmoil of a family left behind.
Full of agreeable performances and a few "aha" moments that most filmmakers would kill for, but it never comes together in any meaningful way.
A wonderful mess of a film - as lovably neurotic and unstable as the webslinger himself.
"The Amazing Spider-Man" plays things agonizingly safe, and while the film isn't without a heartbeat, its failure to take any chances keeps it from flight.
A curious twist on the body swap comedy, with its talented creator and stars ostensibly pulling a switcheroo with a group of exponentially less talented people.
Clobbers you with stupidity so often that you eventually stop noticing.
If [Jaden Smith] wants a career in film, he'll need to do better than this.
Just by avoiding the haze of perfunctoriness that envelops so many sequels, "300: Rise Of An Empire" is a success.
How entertaining could a heavy-handed drama about the 2010 U.S. foreclosure crisis - one with a comically bad climax - possibly be? Pretty entertaining, it turns out.
The Jackie Robinson story has always been more than deserving of a gaudy big-screen telling, and Helgeland is happy to oblige.
The film's end credits feature more unbridled creativity than most films employ in their entireties.
In all its binge-drinking, profanity-laced, vomit-soaked glory, the film's stupefying lack of self-awareness ends up being its biggest enemy.
It seems unlikely to join the director's "The Rock" and "Armageddon" as part of the prestigious Criterion Collection, but it's upper echelon [Michael] Bay.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The end result, while uneven, is appropriately stark, mournful, and gripping, making a deep impression on the landscape of American history on film.
There's a better, deeper movie waiting to be made from the subject matter, but until then "The Finest Hours" will do just fine, a classic case of good being good enough.
Take this one with a chaser of your favorite "Die Hard" memories and hope that the series goes out on a higher note. John McClane deserves better.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's a small miracle that the picture doesn't lean too heavily on one particular topic du jour - bullying - and a major miracle that it's a respectable film, to boot.
"Chef" might not be the return to form that Favreau and his fans were hoping for, but it's a gentle reminder of his charm, a charm that's gone unattended for far too long.
Cut-rate CGI, shaky performances, and a frequently unintelligible screenplay sink the ship.
Funny (often intentionally!), ferociously unsexy, and roundly entertaining from beginning to end.
There are real treasures to be had here, the most prestigious of which is an effortless turn from Benedict Cumberbatch as Julian Assange.
"The Fault In Our Stars" is a top-tier tearjerker and a veritable shoo-in for all future "movies that will make you bawl" lists.
If action is your cinematic elixir of choice, "Fast & Furious 6" won't just sate your thirst - you'll be blackout drunk by the end credits.
It's hard to shake the feeling of a better movie being trapped inside a bad movie's body.
Between Washington's singular performance and Zemeckis' extraordinary direction, "Flight" sees one of the more revelatory actor/director combinations in recent memory.
For anyone willing to brave some tonal inconsistencies, its rewards are real.
Its most interesting lines are on the foreheads of its stars, more than ever imbuing the film with the kind of world weariness that can't be faked.
It's loud and dumb, sure. But it's affable and funny in ways the original wasn't.
The film's aim overreaches its grasp, but its shortcomings make it no less worth the trip. And "trip" is the only word for it.
The screenplay is abysmal, the performances are lifeless, and Alvarez's direction does nothing but rip pages out of Raimi's playbook.
The film skillfully balances seriousness and spectacle, its surplus of rousing action beats ensuring that no one regrets the IMAX 3D surcharge.
Dear devotees of finely drawn, understated cinema - here's your exit. This is "Escape Plan," a cinematic universe in which Stallone and Schwarzenegger play geniuses.
A fun performance from Copley and just enough moments of self-reflexive absurdity make "Hardcore Henry" an adequate arcade-style brawler with a few nice tricks up its sleeve.
Vacuum-packed free of charm and charisma.
Co-lead Ari Graynor gives the sort of breakout performance that the film requires.
The kind of timeless, rib-sticking drama that moviegoers often lament the loss of, only to ignore when they actually come around. Don't make that mistake here.
"Godzilla" circa 2014 towers over the majority of its monster movie brethren.
An experience not unlike downloading a once trendy pop song on iTunes, only to discover it's been feebly re-recorded.
The third act of "The Gift" is so gross, so exploitative that it's a wonder it made it from page to screen uncontested.
The wretchedness on display here is stunning, as if the screenplay was spat out by a musty, old Commodore 64 possessed by the spirit of Ed Wood.
Worthy of its subject and the dollars of music and film fans alike. As roundly entertaining as any biopic in recent memory.
A deformed composite of every buddy comedy ever made, sliced and diced to the point of total anonymity. The characters aren't buddies and the premise isn't comedic.
Visually? Sure, it's impressive. But on all other fronts it leaves nothing but a couple muddy footprints and a signpost of misplaced potential.
This remake not only fails to justify its own existence, it very nearly calls into question the necessity of the material in any form.
Amidst a couple of nice action beats, there's plenty of stilted dialogue, poorly drawn characters, and heaps of generic rock music.
No good, impossibly living down to the comedic wasteland that was "Tammy."
Wan has done an admirable job salvaging the project, but it might have been more at home in the salvage yard, among other abandoned films lost to time and circumstance.
A beautifully brutal work that pulls zero punches, gives zero damns, and willfully mucks around in the muddy moral waters that comprise war.
Michael B. Jordan and Octavia Spencer are particularly good in the film.
[Its] target audience should adore the characters, the visuals, and the music, but more importantly, they'll be bequeathed with a message worthy of their hearts and minds.
As Tim Burton films go, "Frankenweenie" is as visually keyed-in as any.
A painfully straightforward and frequently predictable thriller whose primary redeeming feature is a leading man that deserves better.
Butterfield is excellent in the title role, several cuts above his fellow young cast members.
Segel sells the performance by not overselling it, comfortably meeting viewers halfway between imitation and obfuscation.
A limp, unoriginal, and disheveled script read by a cast that doesn't seem to be able to make any sense of it, either.
Even if Pacino's singing voice leaves much to desired, his performance doesn't. Much like the film itself, it's all in the execution.
Although Tom Hooper's film is ostensibly about Lili Elbe (nee Einar Wegener), it's Alicia Vikander as Elbe's spouse Gerda whose star rises ever higher here.
Even though the narrative lacks propulsion, "Dallas Buyers Club" is a welcome acting showcase for two likable leads.
"The Croods" survives an unsteady second act thanks to a sturdy beginning (including a lovely introductory sequence) and an even sturdier conclusion.
In someone else's hands, "Crimson Peak" might have come off as a costume drama shot out of a cannon, but del Toro's is, crucially, a costume drama shot by a cannon.
Funny and scary and surprising and everything found footage horror should be.
Coogler and company get the essence of "Rocky," from the Italian Stallion's rambling, close-mouthed monologues to the woodwind and horn-based score to the cornball montages.
At least Bardem continues to make the case that he doesn't have a bad performance in him, even in a film as lackluster as this.
An impossibly sparse indie thriller with a cast of five and not much more going on that its title suggests - which is precisely why it works.
At best, "The Conjuring" is a drop or two of rain in the middle of a decades-long horror drought. It won't tide anyone over for more than a couple hours.
A goofy mess whose screws aren't loose, but missing entirely.
Although "Concussion" goes light on Roger Goodell and [his stooges], enough jabs land to make it a passable indictment.
This is the Bermuda Triangle of sci-fi - where logic and clarity vanish without a trace.
The story doesn't work nearly as well in live action, losing the buffer zone of disbelief inherent in Disney's classic animated version.
An unwieldy and frequently tasteless mishmash of gang violence, socioeconomics, and sexual politics.
Nothing here compares to the spastic, crackling electricity of the interrogation scene between Batman and the Joker in "The Dark Knight."
A slice of leftover science fiction warmed in a hopelessly outdated conventional oven. One bite hot, gooey goodness, the next cold and undercooked.
It's a handful of moments between chimps that make "Dawn" worthwhile, with a philosophical exchange between Caesar and his right-hand ape, Koba, making a crater-sized impact.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The closest we've come to a Will Ferrell Greatest Hits movie - not at all a bad thing.
Frothy enough to conceal its own undercurrent of mindless action sludge.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's an absolute joy to see Lloyd Christmas again, and Carrey seems impossibly revitalized.
Free of the extraneous nuts and bolts that so often come with crime dramas, turning simple moments like a well-placed umbrella into something genuinely menacing.
Action junkies should delight in "Dredd."
For all of the typical sports movie clichés that pop up in "Draft Day," the pic's place as an NFL-sanctioned puff piece is what's most alarming.
A shooting star of a film that comes dangerously close to succumbing its own scatterbrained screenplay.
There's just enough charm and poignancy here to make it worth a watch. Not a bad start for any first-time filmmaker.
It's not until the third act that we experience a catharsis of violence, and when it happens, it's just not rooted in the reality of the film.
The pic's charismatic cast turns the skeletal narrative into something functional, making for a surprisingly pleasant ride.
If vomit could vomit, the upshot might resemble alleged comedy "Dirty Grandpa" and its titular performance from 72 year-old screen icon Robert De Niro.
It wields taboo like a cheap firecracker with a makeshift fuse, concurrently panicky and confrontational and overconfident, much like its 15 year-old lead character.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to tell if directors Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud faced interference on the part of the studio, but the film lacks any discernible spark beyond frenzied goofiness.
Vaughn fans will find enough laughs to justify the two hours, but the tonal issues will make it a hard sell for anyone else.
What begins promisingly enough ends up a gratuitously violent, underwritten, depressing scrap heap of a movie that aims for two audiences and misses both.
Not all of it hits its mark, but when the picture starts to gain momentum at the hour mark, its distinctiveness sets in. And it's almost startling.
As fresh and well meaning as it is problematic, taking a new comedy staple - the bromance - and flipping it upside down.
Van Sant's direction isn't nearly as flashy as it was in 2009's "Milk," but he provides the right amount of visual propulsion to keep the story moving along.
MacFarlane's aim is true when it comes to the pic's continuous meta-commentary.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An ugly, stupid, pointless debacle that doubles down on the disappointment of its predecessor.
It's been four years since Ben Affleck directed "Argo." It feels like a hundred.
A staggering work of absolute confidence and absolute uncertainty that endeavors to both embody and crack the great conundrum of faith.
With some audacity and ingenuity, "Hidden Figures" might have been something extraordinary. Instead, it's merely about something extraordinary.
Verhoeven's first film in ten years - and his first deliriously twisted one in much longer - is quite a rebirth for a filmmaker long assumed lost.
Equal parts motion picture and grief support group; a frequently eye-popping fantasy drama defined by unrelenting, one-track weepiness.
A beautiful, bewildering film that bounces from haunting to overblown and back again without a moment's notice, ending up an oddity most befitting of its subject.
Astonishing technical filmmaking that never quite graduates to anything more.
Wilson's text is a phenomenally layered character study and acting showcase. And Washington, Davis, and most of their co-stars are more than up for it.
Great performances abound, mixing with some magnificent photography to form one of the premier family dramas of 2016.
A terrible story told terribly.
There are moments in "Why Him?" in which Cranston is so much better than what the material calls for or deserves that his ability as an actor becomes funny in itself.
Led by Affleck's superior performance, the movie is an obvious awards season frontrunner, a bandwagon nearly filled. Get on board.
Think "Event Horizon," only less romantic.
A routine CGI extravaganza primarily interested in creating a Pavlovian response every time someone or something familiar appears.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "La La Land" is a mirage, a self-satisfied illusion that tries and fails to sanctify a heap of classics that don't require its sanctification.
A loud, ridiculous laugh riot.
Despite a surfeit of nice period visual touches, [Hancock's] soft sensibilities relieve a juicy story of its juice, until all that's left is a blandly edible burger biopic.
Violently superficial.
Destined to find life on DVD - as a coaster.
It's no masterwork, but [James Gunn's] ride-or-die fans would be remiss to miss this freakish fruit of his Marvel Studios labor.
Vogt-Roberts and his editor indiscriminately wallop us with action, darting from character to character and scene to scene, none of it making any impact at all.
Marvel fans that moonlight as undiscerning gorehounds just might find Valhalla in "Logan," but the project goes out of its way to give everyone else the cold, dead shoulder.
It's because of Kaluuya that Peele's commentary remains intelligible throughout, even as the movie leaps over logical chasms and loads up on hammy supporting performances.
[The film is] notable in its own flaky, freaky way, its visual peaks and narrative valleys neatly summing up the bizarro career of its director.
Charlie Day and Ice Cube will live to crack wise another day. "Fist Fight," on the other hand, is where laughter goes to die.
Accompanied by a truckload of alien intestines and yet another unlikely performance from Matt Damon, "The Great Wall" can't help but make a monster-sized impression.
The worst thing to happen to fictional Seattle since Frasier bedded Roz.
While "Exodus" may require Moses-like patience, it's likely to reward the faithful.
The movie's exceptional second half closes in on establishing its lead as the defining action antihero of the decade. "Chapter 3" just might get him there.
Killer jokes, stunning animation, Easter eggs aplenty, and then a Lego brick wall. Action movie tedium sets in, accompanied by a noticeable downtick in sight gags.
[Driver lifts] a very good drama into the heavens with an indispensably rich, textured performance, one that reconfigures all notions of what the actor is capable of.
A poignant, often hilarious tapestry of family and femininity and masculinity and mortality anchored by two of the most undervalued actresses in the world.
Finally, a film to answer the age-old question: is a balding, potbellied, snaggletoothed Matthew McConaughey enough to carry a feature length motion picture?
At once austere and salacious, grim and bubbly, the picture reminds that film is truly a limitless medium.
It only exists to be forgotten - once it's pried a hundred million dollars or so from the clutches of hopelessly optimistic comedy fans. Don't let it.
It's about as good as "A Very Harold & Kumar Christmas," which is to say not very, leaning all too heavily on drug use for comedy.
Conventional storytelling in its most muscular form.
A loudly inconsistent work that ranges from terrible to hilarious to, finally, pretty good.
An utterly ordinary found footage film straightjacketed by a prestigious but dusty property.
As cold as the Hudson River in January.
A base, sleepy exercise in horror that doesn't deserve its cast or an audience.
A tremendous walk-and-talk romance that would work just fine devoid of context. But it's that context that puts it over the top - into "best of the year" territory.
The film suffocates viewers with its sound mix and mind-bendingly stupid story developments that not even the most gullible "Friday The 13th" victim would enact.
Over the film's final forty minutes, the laughs and disbelief both begin to pile up and the picture finally grazes its target.
In crossing potboiler and art film streams, David Mackenzie and Taylor Sheridan have come up with something distinct, if not groundbreaking.
A gorgeous, stirring film that doesn't just rank among the best remakes of Disney's current live-action renaissance. It ranks among their best, period.
It's content to remain in sub-lowbrow land for the duration, except when it feels like imparting a lofty message it never earns.
A film that's at once as magnanimous and volatile as the art form it's celebrating.
Every last of [Allen's] 80 years is felt in the picture's sleepy narration and leisurely pacing. He's been here, done this, toiled over all of these same spare parts before.
A bona fide comic book hang out movie [wherein the characters lend] any given five-minute stretch five times the personality of the entirety of "Batman V Superman."
[There's comedy here, but] the meal is in the juicy, chin-dripping family dysfunction that's at once commendable in its aim and off the charts bonkers in its execution.
The reality of "Jason Bourne" is one of obligation and monotony, as if it's not Bourne with a gun perpetually to his head, but the people writing him.
A western on autopilot.
Condon's film is just about what it should be: A fevered, overblown love letter to a classic. To heights it knows it couldn't hope to reach.
[The film] doesn't just want our neck hairs at attention. No, it wants our hearts and minds, too, and for eighty-four collar-tightening minutes, it gets them.
[Peter Berg] has turned catastrophe into a state-of-the-art theme park ride, forgoing tact for giant, whooshing thrills - and the results are undeniably impressive.
[Once again] Zemeckis seems more concerned with the process than the outcome, resulting in a film that might have been interesting to make but isn't very interesting to watch.
A belated, gaseous sequel that slowly burns off its fumes of disappointment until all that's left is a flaming hull of misery.
"Moana" might be [Walt Disney Animation Studio's] best since 1994's "The Lion King."
As Yates halfheartedly shepherds "Beasts" towards its inevitable sequels, there's only one real surprise: that the screenplay, by Rowling herself, is the weakest link.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the premier extraterrestrial films of the century.
The visuals are lush, the performances are lived-in, and the story is lyrical, if painstakingly subdued.
An amazing true story (Hurrah!) not told very well (Hiss!) - a war movie at war with itself.
"Doctor Strange" is where the welcome wears out, where Marvel's shortcomings take center stage and play a thousand encores.
Suddenly, [Hall], who's always been a bright spot is an eclipse, crossing arduous emotional terrain with ease and finding moments of dignity and grace in mental illness.
One of 2016's very best films, thick and intoxicating, whooshing and thumping like a subwoofer for the entirety of its lengthy running time.
The movie approximates the boredom of life as a Tom Cruise stunt double.
In a time when moviegoers can't seem to escape the onslaught of sequels, remakes, and reboots, "The Accountant" comes as an exclamatory lesson in careful wish making.
The movie is bad and dull, and then bad and dull and gratuitously violent, not even finding a trace of guilty fun in its narrative dumpster diving.
"The Birth Of A Nation" might well be a milestone of indie cinema; one that, on its own merits, is deserving of any awards attention that comes its way.
A Timothy Walter Burton greatest hits movie: a few moments of ethereal genius, some swings toward narrative ruin, and a whole lot of tedium.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The script accentuates its clichés with well-rounded characters and real-life heartbreak, carrying it high above its Disney sports movie relatives.
By the hour mark the film has built up a head of steam, with Hahn laying comedic waste to every scene she's in.
A subpar creature feature with delusions of grandeur and a cheat of a twist ending.
A two-hour flatline, best experienced in the form of its trailers or its soundtrack or anything but the film itself.
An unusual, intermittently fascinating web of sociopolitical commentary and thrills carried painlessly by one of the great baby boomer thespians.
A charming but mild comedy defined by a nice performance from Laurie Metcalf as Lady Bird's mother Marion and a handful of appreciably relatable millennial moments.
Branagh commandeers the movie, turning it into a showcase for himself as Poirot. Everyone else is left to circle the drain.
A hasty, disjointed assemblage of two conflicting visions; a bad movie fused to a different bad movie.
McDonagh's livewire screenplay and true direction make the pic a must-see; two Oscar-worthy performances from Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell rocket it into the heavens.
An unfunny, unpleasant, unabashed cash-in.
This is a great, lively film defined not only by the joy inherent in music, but by a pervasive love for human beings, imperfections and all.
A peculiar tug of war between an indie comedian and a multinational conglomerate.
"Suburbicon" isn't as bad as you've heard - it's much worse.
Considering that Lionsgate had seven years to refocus their flagship horror franchise, the whole of "Jigsaw" is puzzlingly undercooked.
Enjoyably nutty even if the thrill of discovery has faded like a latex wolf mask in sunlight.
The film's biggest liability is that it isn't very funny, bereft of the witticisms Baumbach perfected in his collaborations with [Greta] Gerwig.
[Villeneuve] capably traces the broad strokes of Scott's hard-boiled, mostly action-free original, but he bungles the buttoned-up postmodernism.
[Cruise] standing in for a portly, devil-may-care Louisianan is an epic miscast.
It's swallowed up by a style-over-substance approach increasingly at odds with its subject matter.
The movie condenses the complicated Wiseau-Sestero relationship into a broad "two friends take on Hollywood" narrative, robbing the story of so many of its eccentricities.
Writer-director Rian Johnson repeatedly shows an inability to build to moments. His screenplay's biggest beats come off as self-defeating and lifeless.
The late-game casting of Plummer as the famous oil magnate with all the warmth of a velociraptor is a dream, but the elderly character inherently has very little to do.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are some jump scares, one highly predictable twist, and a fair amount of violence, but "The Purge" pretty much begins and ends with its concept.
The movie's tug-of-war between thrills and fuzzy philosophical waxing results in something much too close to a zero-sum game.
Another inimitable chapter in an increasingly fascinating filmography.
Coogler's screenplay (co-written by Joe Robert Cole) gets T'Challa and Erik's conflict exactly right.
The most amateurish, inadvertently funny studio film in recent memory.
As the pic's end titles arrive, we realize just how well it's done its fancy, cagey thing, never compromising and stiffly rebuffing the negative connotations of melodrama.
The pic's transparent award season aspirations create an impassable fissure between subject matter and charisma.
Its only aim is to make us jump, make us laugh, and send us off with a thrilling final shot that's everything a "Cloverfield" fan could want from a prequel.
It's an extraordinary thing for a narrative film to successfully observe its characters like they aren't of its own creation - to make them utterly alive in front of us.
Largely unknown actor Paul Walter Hauser nicks the back half of "I, Tonya" as portly Gillooly goon and Harding bodyguard Shawn Eckhardt.
The pejorative "Oscar bait" is immaterial when it's this good.
As loud and soulless a family movie as there's been in years.
Del Toro's typically lusty visuals and the impressive mix of practical and computer-enhanced effects that comprise his fish-man smother the would-be intricacies of his drama.
As an unfortunately rare Hollywood film created by and starring women, "Pitch Perfect 2" is alarmingly obtuse in its depiction of them.
Ugly, dumb, incoherent, and preposterously silly - a lethal cocktail when heading for the exit is as easy as the press of a button.
An artless, facile gaze at an American icon, a film whose look and dialogue often come off like an adaptation of the back of a vintage Wheaties box.
Its soon-to-be-infamous degloving scene is best watched through splayed fingers. The film itself is best not watched at all.
An uncommonly confident, compelling biographical drama that mostly avoids schmaltz and hagiography.
The whole is less boorish than the original and a few action beats are liable to get the heart racing. But for a series to run out of narrative gas this quickly is revealing.
Between its wonderful voice performances and eye-popping animation, there isn't too much to complain about, especially as a follow-up to Pixar's nadir.
A shark chomping on a discarded typewriter couldn't have come up with something so unintelligible.
Put up against [Wright's] earlier work, it wilts.
Trevorrow makes it cohere, painting an unusual story into something by turns heartfelt and thrilling.
It might be a dirge of a film, but it's a beautiful, textured dirge that hangs in the air long after its last note has been played.
[The film is] its own kind of black magic: an absolutely putrid movie without any of the fun normally associated with putrid movies.
Gadot and Pine [mine] their characters for the kinds of small but meaningful moments that most superhero movies would kill for.
There's a glint of life in this franchise yet.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Moviegoers on the hunt for an Alien fix will get it, even if the picture never quite reconciles its awkward place between prequel and sequel.
"This sounds like an entertaining but far-fetched TV show!" exclaims Efron's character. Oh, we know, Zac. Because it's a "Baywatch" movie. Good joke.
James Gunn has done something few before him have managed: He's followed a great film with an even greater sequel. Hats off, Cheap Trick's "Surrender" on.
The entire picture hinges on one character's hankering for some late-night kayaking.
All killer, no filler.
Vin is king.
A surprisingly dark climax marked with hilariously overwrought lighting is everything to love and hate about "T2 Trainspotting" - and Danny Boyle - all at once.
Michael Bay doesn't make movies anymore; he makes migraine auras.
A lumpy paste of brooding teen drama based entirely on coincidence and action scenes edited so rashly that it'd be tough to know if shots from other movies slipped in.
Rivals "Get Hard" as the worst thing Will Ferrell has ever said "yes" to.
A middling high school action-comedy with dull setpieces; a lesser "Superbad" with superhero cameos.
Although it's absolutely not for casual moviegoers, "mother!" is mandatory viewing for anyone remotely serious about the medium.
[Skarsgård] brings such a delicious physicality to [Pennywise] that he ends up the most compelling clown this side of the late Heath Ledger's Joker. He's remarkable.
A flighty shrimp and grits caper that willfully evokes the best - and a little of the worst - of [Soderbergh's] billion dollar-grossing [Ocean's] trilogy.
Scarily formulaic.
Once it becomes obvious that there's no discernible arc at hand for Ingrid, a sense of inevitability sets in and the unpleasantness of the characters begins to wear.
Contrary to online chatter, the ultimate tragedy of Netflix's "Death Note" adaptation isn't its general infidelity to its source material; it's that it sucks.
A distinctive head rush that pairs a handful of refreshingly earnest performances with a great sense of style.
The superiority of Sheridan's work here isn't just in its tautness - its true victory is in its empathy.
Summer 2017 has given us worse reasons to head to the multiplex, but none have been as dispiritingly lifeless as "The Dark Tower."
Check in for the impressive bursts of violence but be prepared for a surplus of downtime - a near death sentence for a movie called "Atomic Blonde."
The work of a filmmaker conflating his biggest strengths and biggest weaknesses.
For a concurrently dead simple and wildly innovative white knuckler of a war pic, look no further. One of our greats is back with more greatness.
With Reeves' metaphors all face-up, "War" becomes nothing but an awfully literal conclusion of a trilogy that once hinted at much bigger, more symbolic things.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: New shorthand for bloated, empty big screen science fiction.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At 125 minutes, it's a grind that never finds an equilibrium between feel-good comedy and incisive slice of life. And it's never quite funny enough.
Directors Pierre Coffin and Kyle Balda won't win the franchise any new fans here, but it should be enough to keep the old ones firmly on board. For now.
Phenomenally stupid.
A mindwarp of a movie that shares DNA with a few surprising classics.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Blasé characters and tired jump scares [populate] a "Nightmare On Elm Street" redux that swaps out dreams for darkness and an iconic villain for an indistinct one.
It's an agreeable ride and the fact that it treads so little new ground doesn't much detract from its pleasures.
The talented cast and fascinating real life story are enough of a foundation to make it worth the 2-hour sentence.
At least Pacino and Arkin will always have "Glengarry Glen Ross."
With his first feature film, writer-director Theodore Melfi has accomplished what many inveterate filmmakers haven't - he's gotten Bill Murray to come alive.
The film's quantity-over-quality approach affords star Melissa McCarthy the luxury of both owning the film and sharing the glory with a wonderful supporting cast.
For moviegoers looking for sensory overload, this will play particularly well.
It's fan fiction writ large, making it clearer than ever that George Lucas is "Star Wars." With his voice gone, all that's left are tinny reverberations of movie history.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Just nine years after the shot of life that was "Casino Royale," it feels like it's time again to start over. For shame, James.
"Sparkle" has its bright spots - mostly in the middle of the film - and Epps and Ojogo shine.
There's never a moment when Gyllenhaal the actor is on screen. Billy Hope might be his most vibrant work to date, even if the movie doesn't match up.
South Korean filmmaker Joon-ho Bong's latest is a welcome reminder of [sci-fi's] fertile - if often untilled - creative ground.
"Snitch" is passable thanks to a sturdy second act and a decent performance by Dwayne Johnson, but it's never captivating.
James Bond has been relegated to cinematic stupidity before, but demoting the character to this degree of slightness is even more deflating.
As a dark character piece with the occasional big laugh, "The Skeleton Twins" is as much a pleasure to watch as it is to digest once its end credits roll.
An unusually evasive piece of filmmaking - hard to pin down, but all the more worthwhile for its craftiness.
With a seminal lead performance, pools of delectable dialogue, and some editing for the ages, "Steve Jobs" is a must for cinephiles.
It's an over-ambitious pop culture spread that should please hip-hop history buffs and absolutely delight those with a healthy distaste for authority.
The movie isn't as dynamic as it could have been, but it gets to the core of what big, important social change means - and how little glory there is in ground work.
An astoundingly sleek sequel that delivers a steady stream of both rousing action and substantial laughs.
Ultimately, "The To Do List" settles for being intermittently amusing, never living up to the promise of its talented cast.
One recurring gag features Fey's toddler ambling around with a plastic toilet, defecating in the most unseemly of locations. There isn't a better analogy for [the] film.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Come for the cameos, stay for Danny McBride, and come back again for the handful of genuinely deranged sequences that you'll hardly believe exist in a mainstream comedy.
Apatow's descent as a storyteller is continuing, and his ear for comedy isn't at its peak.
A small-minded portrait of subject who's anything but.
It's absolutely impossible not to smile when "The Wonders" hear their song on the radio for the first time.
"That Awkward Moment" is perfectly titled - as in that awkward moment when your romantic comedy isn't at all romantic and often blithely unfunny.
The most useless "Terminator" film to date, one that erases all "Terminator" films to date except the one it needed most to erase - itself.
Worth its weight in junk food.
"Ted 2" sees all of [Seth MacFarlane's] worst proclivities front and center, as shaggy and undisciplined as ever.
The movie is hilarious in fits and starts, but nothing is sustained and every joke, funny or not, is delivered with the dial up to 11.
Ultimately, the entire film plays like a 100-minute deleted scene - shaggy, formless, and voraciously inconsequential.
Its hilarious, mind-bendingly stupid climax is nearly worth the price of admission alone.
A sequel to a surprise but modest hit has no right to be this lackluster.
"Sisters" impossibly comes off like it was conceived, written, and shot in less time than it plays.
The Austin, Texas-centric, green-screen addled cult of Robert Rodriguez has finally collapsed in on itself. All that's left to wonder is if anyone will bother to tell him.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a challenging picture, but it runs the gamut of emotions so well that it's nearly impossible to dislike.
It has "minor classic" written all over it.
"Room" is lowest common denominator goop, so interested in feeling that it neglects to say or do.
"Rock Of Ages" is a soundtrack in search of a story, but it turns its utter disregard for narrative into its strongest ally.
Despite straying from the satiric bent of the original, this edition has plenty to say - and plenty of ways to thrill its audience.
Just interesting and colorful enough to hold a child's attention for 90 minutes but a thundering bore for anyone that's been around the cinematic block.
A bad movie and a frequently unwatchable one, but for the first time in years Sandler and co-writer Tim Herlihy have bothered to write real, actual jokes.
About as much fun as a parking ticket.
[Leads] off with the most poorly shot and edited chase scene in recent memory... so spatially confusing that it might as well have been shot through a kaleidoscope.
B-level sci-fi doesn't have to be this tedious or banal.
An empty, pretty thing... little more than a string of breathtaking vistas best suited for months of playback in the home theater section of your local Best Buy.
"Red 2" is at least as good as its predecessor, if not noticeably better.
A picture of slight charms and minor successes, but they're definitely there for the right audience to discover.
The kind of terrible that doesn't wash out, destined to be remembered among the pantheon of big budget bombs like "The Adventures Of Pluto Nash" and "Cutthroat Island."
If the movie is barely necessary, that doesn't negate its computer-generated pleasures or the presence of Bill Murray, who continues to be great at being Bill Murray.
Roughly as adventurous as a stop at a theme park information center.

Rapper Common's appearance as the pic's bad hitman - again, the movie wants us to think there are hitmen who aren't so bad - is the film in a nutshell.
From a filmmaker whose four features to date average a muscular 96% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, it all makes for an absolutely crushing defeat.
The story is so inconsequential that the best performances in the world would hardly make a dent in its snooze-worthy screenplay.
Built like an old, beat-up bomber - not necessarily the sleekest or most reliable, but perfectly engineered to drop emotional projectiles on its audience.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A work of staggering self-confidence, the kind of movie that believes in itself so completely that audience apathy is all but impossible.
Cinematic without belying its "slice of life" vibe, emotionally enveloping without being saccharine, and wonderfully acted across the board.
Segel and Diaz have some work ahead of them to erase this one from the pop culture DVR.
Although "Psychopaths" is an enjoyably confounding experience, some will be put off by its parade of esoteric ideas. But what a parade it is.
"The Sessions" is a skillfully layered look at the similarities and differences between people of all walks of life.
Oyelowo is the real deal, monumental in a film that isn't, muscling a middling historical drama into something absolutely worth seeing.
Part debacle, part footnote, sure to remind viewers of the better films they could be watching if they weren't such lousy decision makers.
Carell could have given the performance of his life (he doesn't), and the film would have remained a cliché-ridden mess with a narrative built on convenience and coincidence.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [Stiller's] creative fingerprints are few and far between here, the pic's spoon-fed schmaltziness betraying [his] typical satiric edge.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Every penny that "Scary Movie V" earns is cinematic blood money, looted from the pockets of unsuspecting moviegoers.
Viewers raised on "Mary Poppins" will be unable to resist the warm embrace of "Saving Mr. Banks."
There's no heft to the material - only mindless violence - and Blake Lively is absolutely dreadful.
Empty, cynical destruction porn that's twice as dumb as it should be and not half as enjoyable.
Plaza and Duplass do great, believable work, and it's a debut that both writer (Connolly) and director (Trevorrow) can proudly hang their hats on.
The kind of cathartic action pic that's been long absent, reminding us that gritty revenge pieces have their place.
Nearly as narratively compelling as it is viscerally thrilling, "Rush" is Howard's most efficient film since "Apollo 13."
[Rock's] high notes are higher than ever, his penchant for uproarious comedy intact, but his cinematic voice remains inexplicably lost in the din.
"Ruby Sparks" is a uniquely palatable concoction - part Woody Allen, part John Hughes, part Rod Serling.
Bland all the way through, from dialogue to action and everything in between. It's not a missed opportunity - just a total waste of time.
Tragically [combines] its picked-over-thrift-shop visual aesthetic with a shoulder shrug of a plot that feels straight out of a theme park ride queue video.
The comedic equivalent of being whomped in the face with a pillowcase full of nickels.
[Shane] Black's weakest effort in an age, a shoot-from-the-hip P.I. comedy that isn't half as interesting as "Inherent Vice" and barely as funny.
Noticeably disconnected and low on laughs, undoubtedly a symptom of the screenplay's five - count 'em - five different screenwriters.
By the 60-minute mark Lathimos' bag of tricks is empty, kickstarting a long slide into tedium that sinks a project that should have sung.
As joyous a moviegoing experience as 2016 has offered to date, sweet and funny and just dark enough to keep the admittedly imitative story interesting.
A lumbering, outmoded Brachiosaurus of a movie that evokes a few turn-of-the-century thrillers that should not be evoked.
A barely adequate, tonally berserk lyric to the pains of franchise building. In other words, it does absurdly little with a whole lot.
Gorgeous but garbled.
A sweet, good-natured movie whose shortcomings are screamingly obvious, underlined throughout by the same likability that sustains it.
The aim of "Everybody Wants Some!!" is to mirror the warm feelings that come with a good beer buzz. And for that, there are few better options.
Michael Shannon's Elvis alone demands to be experienced. Not for its accuracy, but for its lunacy.
Minimalism is a valid creative choice, but in this case, it renders an extraordinary story very ordinary. And the real-life heroes, flaws and all, were anything but.
Once past a formulaic opening, the picture opens up into something else entirely, ending up as one of the better slasher movies to hit the big screen [in decades].
It doesn't so much revive the franchise as it confirms that it's still breathing. Barely.
Its problems are crippling but not fatal, the film kept afloat by a raft of brilliant performers - even when Singer has no idea what to do with them.
Its visuals are so sharp that they practically smother the rest of the film.

Continues to conflate magical realism with street and stage magic (two distinctly different things) while having nothing interesting to say about either of them.
Few films have ever been less likely to get but more deserving of a sequel.
The year's biggest crowd-pleaser and the spiritual sequel to Ivan Reitman's "Ghostbusters" that die-hards have longed for since 1984 - whether they'll admit to it or not.
"Top Gun" works best as a sort of time capsule, a window into a pretty spectacular decade for big-budget filmmaking.
The movie doesn't have half the personality of the average hound - or even the most entitled housecat.
Purge no more, horror fans. The time has come to return this franchise from whence it came: the recycling bin.
Radcliffe is next-level-good [as Manny], suggesting a talent that's barely been tapped into; an actor that we'll be watching for decades to come.
"The BFG" - character and movie both - is too mild-mannered to induce any seat-springing feelings of joyfulness, but its old-fashioned pleasures are genuine.
An elegant but incomparably dull action adventure movie that makes Peter Jackson's lethargic "King Kong" remake look like an EDM festival by comparison.
Refn has always been a go-big-or-go-home filmmaker, but here that sensibility betrays him.
"The Shallows" is just that, often ankle-deep and unable to see past its own snout. But there's just as much good here as bad.
Its funniest [element] is the framing issues caused by the height disparity between its stars.
Intermittently cute and nothing more.
Even if you've seen these ingredients before, you've never seen them prepared quite like this.
"The Conjuring 2" is one of the premier horror sequels of all time, not just improving on its predecessor but retroactively improving it.
A surprisingly soulful character study dressed up as a special effects extravaganza. For every thing "Warcraft" does wrong - and there are many - it does something very right.
Accomplishes nothing that any given episode of the original animated series didn't - only at five times the length and a thousand times the budget.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An atmospheric, frequently creepy zombie thriller that strikes a nice balance between horror and action-adventure, leaning on familiarity but never abusing it.
The movie equivalent of ordering a popsicle on a sweltering summer day - only to be served the stick.
"The Words" is an elegant piece of entertainment, replete with an understated but sweeping score, unexpected period piece vignettes, and melodramatic but universal themes.
Occasionally [spikes] into dopey fun but mostly [drags] the lake of Frankenstein adaptations past for story beats that are beyond well worn.
